												This is easily one of the worst zombie-themed games I've ever played.Supposedly, developers tried to make something like a squad-based survival simulator. The final product is not a simulator, it's not about surviving (if we're not talking about user surviving through the UI), and squad-based part is just pontless.Every aspect of the game represents raw incompetence of the developers -- game is bugged, UI is ridiculous, gameplay is extremely boring (if you'll last more than 1 hour, like I did, you're supposed to be awarded with a medal), fighting system is just plainly lame.The game has active pause (you can prace Space to pause the game and give orders to your survivors). Presumably, this was implemented to introduce tactics to the game. Alas, this effort was fruitless -- fights are boring and repetitive. Most of the fights are ending up in user, luring enemies into some trap and then activating it. There's no tactics to it, honestly, it's just a waste of time.There's a ton of useless mechanics. For example, your character can randomly start bleeding after he was wounded. You'll be bleeding for the whole duration of the level (it won't stop), yet you won't lose any HP for that. Why was that implemented? Because it attracts zombie in a bigger radius around you. But since you're walking faster then they do, they'll soon forget about you and would roam around their location aimlessly (pathfinding is awful here too, by the way).The weapon system is plainly lame -- you can only hold 1 weapon, and if you want to turn on some switch, you first have to hide the weapon, then use the switch, then take out the weapon again. Developers couldn't care less about usability, I think.One of the bugs that I've found in my short session was inability to launch game in windowed mode -- all my efforts lead to a point where my inventory disappeared alongside with all of the texts in the game. I was unable to fix it, so, obviously enough, I've decided to just uninstall.Will I recommend this game? Never. I may recommend to try it to people with really low self-esteem that are enjoying UI masochism and poor gameplay.I'd rate the game 2.0 out of 10.0, and would NOT recommend it to anyone.

												A frustrating but overall nice turn-based/real-time strategy/RPG hybrid game.The gameplay is very similar to Icewind Dale. You get to control a party of survivors in real-time, however you can pause the game at any moment to choose what should be that character's next action.The action is very intense as you can often become overcrowded with dozens of zombies in just a mere few seconds. The feeling of the weapons, from baseball bats, pistols, to even grenades is perfect. Letting a zombie to slowly walk right up to your character's face to finally blow his/her brains out with a well timed shot is deliciously rewarding. The game world, characters and zombies are all well designed, but the voice acting is atrocious. The game is well presented, the graphics are good, but the camera system can be extremely frustrating to control at times. Getting used to the poor camera system and controls can be a hard task.The game uses a checkpoint system to save your progress during missions, but they're quite rare and some checkpoints are optional. These are often placed in an alternate route and protected by a bunch of zombies. While the checkpoint system builds up tension and greatly increases the challenge, it only leads to frustration because you can easily loose an hour of gameplay if the game crashes (and it does often in some missions).I would recommend to buy a 4-pack when on sale (or even better, get it in a 1 dollar bundle) to play with your friends because playing solo can be VERY tiring as you'd have to micro-manage everything.There's no achievements in this game.

												I think this game gets more abuse than it deserves and I think herein lays great potential for a new take on zombie games.  Not that I'm recommending this game on its potential alone.Where there can be filler sections, there are a good smattering of genuinely exciting sections where you have to tactically micromanage your team's position, weaponry and targets to escape the hordes that are rolling inexorably over your position.  Cramped indoors or built up urban areas add to this excitement, where every move is key.  I found the game's difficulty relatively on the low side though (no difficulty settings either), and was never short of ammunition but the game is swift to punish carelessness as your guys can become zombie chow in 2 seconds if left unattended next to a hungry undead.The story plays homage to all the zombie cliches in a suitably brief (only about 8 or so hours of gameplay so it doesn't outstay it's welcome) tour of all the standard zombie invasion locations.  There are rough bits granted, and it could be buggy at times.  I had at least one crash to desktop, and sometimes injured zombies would suddenly stand up many metres from where you had smashed/blasted them to.  Also there are some truly bizarre choices at times (the end credits ends on a box of cereal) and the ending was a bit of a flop, leaving me with a bit of an anticlimx as the only thing resembling a boss fight coming on the penultimate level.I will allow there are better zombie games out there.  Though if you love all things zombies and tire of the standard run and gun zombie kill-a-thon then this could be the game for you.  Definitely pick it up on sale.

Posted: February 26, 2014
												Despite of all the hate surrounding this game I'm really enjoying it. It has some flaws, of course, but which game hasn't them?Commands: Commands are quite simple (but not simplistic) and respond pretty well. I don't really understand why people complain so much about the controls, mine always worked well. Maybe people were mistaking commands (ordering your party to walk into an enemy instead of fighting it - I did it a few times). Maybe devs released a patch or something, I don't know. LMB to walk and RMB to fight. The guy you're directly controlling will keep hitting the enemy until you tell him to stop or until he runs out of stamina. Problem here are those guys you're not controlling - once you order them to attack, sometimes they keep attacking, sometimes they do it once and stop. I discovered that, most often, you give them a gun, you'll have to place an attack command for each shot; you give them a melee weapon, they'll do the job until stamina goes outCamera can be controlled with mouse or keyboard. However, the mouse can only hover the camera throughout the scenario - if you want to turn the camera (and it does 360°, to the left and to the right), you have to use the keyboard, so controlling the camera can be a little tricky. I ended up preferring controlling the camera solely by the keyboard, which is not really difficult once you get used to it. Camera can also be freely moved when you pause the gameMouse scroll zooms in and out is. Problem here is that the game didn't recognize the scroll on my wireless mouse (which didn't happen on my wired mouse) - so I had to rebind it to up/down. In the end, I didn't use it much because even though the zoom in is really "in", the zoom out is not that "out", it is pretty much the FOV you'll be using anyway, so it's not that useful.  Apart from that, both wired and wireless mouse work perfectly. Keys are rebindable, by the way. The characters you are playing with can be selected either by mouse (clicking on the character or in the hud) or by pressing F1-F4 (I'll talk about the hud later on)Graphics and sound:Graphics are pretty good. The story is presented via cutscenes in such a comic book style which is pure eye candy, really well done. In-game graphics are also very good - there's blood and corpses everywhere, and the dead zombies (I mean, those you sent back to death) remain in the scenarioOverall sound is great - the zombies' moaning, the munching, even the doc's wheelchair makes noise when he moves. Voice acting, on the other hand…not so great. I don't know if they tried to parody old movies or if it was just bad choice, either way it didn't work. Thankfully, it only plays during cutscenes (and if you manage to blow a zombie's head off)GameplayIt's a strategy game, so run and gun will only get you eaten - which I soon discovered. There's a pause button ('space bar') so make use of it. Pausing and telling you're character what to do tends to work pretty well. Unfortunally you can't give commands in-a-row Be advised not to bleed and be careful when running. Zombies will smell you if you're bleeding and will hear you if you run, so they will start to chase you. Besides, running burns stamina, and you may run out of it right before a fight - and you can't fight without stamina.Problem is, zombies will not chase you forever. If you're on an open space, you can just keep walking. The zombies will start giving up on chasing you until there's only 2 or 3 left on your tail.Talking about stamina, always keep an eye on it. If your guys run out of stamina while fighting, they'll stop the fight to take a break - meaning, they will just stand there taking hits until they eventually die. Trust me, you don't want to die on this gameInventory management is neat - drag and drop all the way. Items can be rearranged, dropped on the floor or  given to another character and weapons take up to 3 spaces (each character has 12 inv spaces), no issues hereGame hud displays the characters you've met so far, the inventory (which you can hide by pressing 'I') and 4 buttons, each one representing walk, run, select group and camera mode. Select group means select the whole group and give them all the same order (the whole group can also be select via mouse). Camera mode 'on' means that the camera will follow the character you're controlling; 'off', that you'll have to control the camera yourself. Pretty good in my opinionAvoid alt-tab at all costs. Sometimes, when you alt-tab back to the game, your inventory is gone. I mean, it's there but you can't see it, making the game unplayable. So, if you need to alt-tab, I highly advise you to do it right after saving Micromanaging can became another issue - your party does not think for themselves, so you need to give your partners orders for every little thing, which may become a little tiring. Not an issue for me, actually, but some people just don't like itSomething I really missed is a bit more of exploration - you know, search locks, garbage cans, drawers, cabinets etc. Items are just dumped anywhere and they have a green glow - so you can't really miss themThe real problem in this game, the one that is most likely to make you stop playing it for good, is the saving system. The game doesn't allow manual save and: I) save points are oddly placed; II) can only be used once; and III) all your characters have to stand within the save radius in order to the game be saved. This, my friends, can be a pain, because if you die or if the games crashes you may easily lose one hour of gameplayHere is how the save system works: save points are represented as closed manholes. Once the manhole is used, it opens and it can't be used anymore - so you know exactly which ones were used and which ones were not. Pretty cool if there were plenty of them. However, in some levels you'll desperate cry for save points, while in others you may even not use all of them. Besides, you have to have all your crew together at the same save point for it to work - sometimes it's nice because you can have the whole group to walk through the save point and keep it for later, but if you left someone behind due to the micromanaging thing, you'd better be sure that you left no zombie behind eitherI don't play multiplayer games, so I can't talk about it, sorry. And I think it has any achievements, but as I don't care for them I'm not really sureConclusion:This game is not, by no means, unplayable. Devs could had made a few things better, of course, and the saving system can be frustrating at times but the game does the job to keep you entertained. Zombies are slow as they should be and, for what it is, it is a good gameEven though I don't recommend it getting it at full price, if you can cope with the saving system just wait for a sale to grab itAll in all, I give it a 7 out of 10 - because I really liked it and I think it worth the money I paid for it

												Avoid this game. I'm sorry but while I do love me some realtime isometric squad based tactics abnd the zombie story and characters seem interesting I have to say this game should be avoided. An example of a solid concept ruined by shoddy execution.I'm sorry, at this point I cannot recommend this game. v1.1. I can't, I honestly can't.  I like the premise and what it's trying to do but the execution is in a word, sloppy. The interface should not be an obstacle to the game and unresponsive controles should not be part of the challenge. When you sometimes have to click 3-4 times to get a character to even move, that is a recipe for frustration and disaster for while your shosen chracter will not respond the zombies around you will respond quite readily. Then there are the crashes., which are made doubly frustrating because the game uses a checkpoint system so you can lose a whole lot of progress, just because the game decided to crash. Did I mention that each save/checkpoint can only be used once per mission and there are usually no more than 4 for an entire mission? So you can't even mitigate the crash problem by 'saving frequently. It is also far too easy to accidentally drop an item from your inventory, which in the heat of a fight... can be a problem.Overall, the game needs quite a few fixes and sadly those will have to be fan/community made since the devs have pretty much said 'nope we're done, enjoy'. Understand that when the game works, when the controls choose to respond and the game doesn't bother to crash... it is a good game...these moments arem at least for me (and quite a few others), few and far between. a textbook example of a good concept and good mechanics cripppled by poor implementation and interface.

Posted: August 26, 2012
												Trapped Dead is a below average tactical strategy game with lots of gory zombie goodness.  Unfortunately the title is marred by a multiplayer mode that appears non-functional, wonky camera controls and an exceedingly slow pace in the normal movement mode.  While the graphics are quite well done and do a good job of adding to the immersion, unfortunately the voice acting is so bad it immediately rips you right back out.  The music is an ambient and repetitive, although fitting for the slow pacing of the game.  Widescreen modes and the Steam Overlay are supported but the game controller is not.  Most frustrating about the title however is that your death will often be the result of the frustrating camera controls and not a a tactical error, and combined with a checkpoint save system almost guarantees frustration at certain challenging points in the campaign.  Altogether Trapped Dead disappoints and should only be picked up by genre collectors or die hard zombie enthusiasts.

												This game's had a lot of negative reviews but if you want some cheap and cheerful zombie meets axe to the head action it's not that bad.It may be slow paced, it may feel a little bit on the dated side, and if you're looking for a story then look elsewhere, it's just a case of getting through the levels and finding ammo or the next survivor to join you, but it's a decent enough squad-based zombie fest all the same. Screenshots and reviews don't do it justice, the graphics are ok, nothing outstanding but acceptable, the gameplay is simple enough ( select a squad member then click where you want him to go and which way to face him). inventory is a basic affair but you can swap items between characters. Tactics aren't too involved, mainly choosing when to run and use stamina (which you also need for melee attacks) or stand and shoot with your limited ammo. I found the best way was to lure the zombies towards a squad member then get another character behind them with a bat or, even better, an axe and then thwack 'em. First aid is administered using the doctor with med packs but these are in limited supply, pistols, shotguns, grenades, all the usual suspects are there.There aren't too many pickups so ammo is scarce at the start, a few more things to find (and maybe chests etc) would've been a nice addition, levels can feel a bit sparse except for the zombies and some loot locations, instead of stuff lying around, would have given it and extra degree of gameplay. All the negatives aside it's a fun enough game if you just want some relaxed undead bashing.....always a good thing in my opinion !

												It's rare for me to complete single player games. Normally I loose interest before I get to the end. Not with Trapped Dead. I played it through to the end and loved all of it.The story isn't great (it's no Walking Dead), but it's just good enough to create a relaxing b-movie feel (which is almost tradition for zombie movies!). The engine and the controls are a bit... quirky, at times, but for some reason those quirks created character rather than annoyance. It's like that cute lovable dog that's the runt of the litter.The game mechanics aren't at all innovative. It's got your classic RPG features that you would expect. I felt that this game has just the right amount of complexity that I felt challenged, but not so much complexity that I felt like playing it required lots of effort. I could get home from work and put some casual hours into it with what was left of my brain and still feel a strong sense of reward for my in-game accomplishments.The game is well balanced. It's consistent: once you understand how to play it, you can enjoy it all without feeling stuck or getting confused.If you like RPGs and zombie movies and if you can drop your standards below the likes of Baldur's Gate and XCOM, then you'll probably enjoy this.

												I rarely touch games with Metacritic scores below the 60's, but during one Spring evening, for no particular reason, I was compelled to play Trapped Dead... and I'm glad I did.Trapped Dead is played primarily in bird's eye view. The camera is adjustable, but the controls needed to do so will take some getting used to.In real time strategy fashion, the player dictates the action of several characters, instructing them to move, attack, or swap inventory. Unfortunately, the controls here too can often times be unresponsive and confusing, leading to much frustration.Despite the poor controls and optimization (you might suffer from frame drops), I found myself falling in love with Trapped Dead. Its strategic elements are unique and rewarding. Skills also come into play as you must learn to manage your characters efficiently.This game is definitive proof to me that review scores are all too subjective. All flaws aside, I'd certainly recommend Trapped Dead.Grade: B-
